temp.fibHeap.stixar.graph.conn
Class Transitivity

java.lang.Object
  temp.fibHeap.stixar.graph.conn.Transitivity

public class Transitivity
extends java.lang.Object

Transitivity Algorithms.

The transitive closure of a directed graph G=(V,E) is a directed graph G=(V,E*) where E* contains all the edges in E and in addition has the following transitivity property:

(u,v) in E* and (v,w) in E* implies (v,w) in E*

Transitive closure is basically a cubic time operation (O(|V||E|)) and E* can contain up to quadratic space. For these reasons, can be difficult to compute transitive closure for large graphs.

For the case of an arbitrary digraph, this algorithm works as follows. First, strong components are computed. Then the quotient graph is constructed, which is acyclic. The quotient graph is then topologically sorted, and in reverse topological order, each node's reachable set is computed as the union of the reachable sets in all its outgoing edges. The process of unioning and storing the reachable sets can be much more costly than the rest of the algorith, which is linear. Acyclic graphs are treated similarly, but the strong components computation is skipped.

The transitive reduction of a directed graph G=(V,E) is a graph Gred=(V,Ered) with a minimal number of edges whose transitive closure is equal to the transitive closure of g. If G is acyclic, then Ered is a subset of E and is uniquely defined. If G is not acyclic, then these properties do not necessarily hold. Moreover, if G is not acyclic, then finding a smallest subset of edges E- from G such that the transitive closure of (V,E-)) equals the transitive closure of G is NP-complete.

Hence we supply methods for computing the transitive closure and reduction. of acyclic and arbitrary digraphs.

In addition, we supply a method for calculating a compact representation of the transitive closure of a digraph which allows for storing the transitive closure in a structure which is likely to be much smaller than quadratic.

The transitive closure algorithm, which is also used in the transtive reduction computations, is inspired by the thesis of Nuutila, but implements a simpler multi-pass method.

Method Detail

closure

public static ByteNodeMatrix closure(Digraph dg)
Compute a reachability matrix for the digraph.

A reachability matrix allows for constant time reachability querying at the expense of the space used to store the matrix. If the graph is large or the number of reachability queries does not exceed |V|2 / log(|V|), then using the compactClosure(temp.fibHeap.stixar.graph.Digraph) method is recomended.

Parameters:
dg - a digraph.
Returns:
a matrix whose entries (i,j) are 1 if i can reach j in the graph dg, and 0 otherwise.

compactClosure

public static NodeMatrix<java.lang.Boolean> compactClosure(Digraph dg)
Produce a compact representation of the transitive closure of an arbitrary digraph.

A compact representation of a reachability matrix is created in which reachability queries are guaranteed to take O(log(|V|) time, and is oftentimes much faster. While the space required by the representation can vary a lot, it is typically linear if it is handed a randomly generated graph.

Parameters:
dg - the graph whose closure is to be computed.
Returns:
a pseudo-matrix which returns true upon a call to .get(Node u, Node v) exactly if v is reachable from u in dg. The returned matrix throws an UnsupportedOperationException if its set method is used.

acyclicClosure

public static ByteNodeMatrix acyclicClosure(Digraph dg)
Compute a reachability matrix for an acyclic digraph.

A reachability matrix allows for constant time reachability querying at the expense of the space used to store the matrix. If the graph is large or the number of reachability queries does not exceed |V|2 / log(|V|), then using the compactClosure(temp.fibHeap.stixar.graph.Digraph) method is recomended.

Parameters:
dg - a digraph.
Returns:
a matrix whose entries (i,j) are 1 if i can reach j in the graph dg, and 0 otherwise.

acyclicClosure

public static ByteNodeMatrix acyclicClosure(Digraph dg,
                                            CList<Node> tsort)
Compute a reachability matrix for an acyclic digraph.

A reachability matrix allows for constant time reachability querying at the expense of the space used to store the matrix. If the graph is large or the number of reachability queries does not exceed |V|2 / log(|V|), then using the compactClosure(temp.fibHeap.stixar.graph.Digraph) method is recomended.

Parameters:
dg - a digraph.
tsort - a topologically sorted list of nodes in dg.
Returns:
a matrix whose entries (i,j) are 1 if i can reach j in the graph dg, and 0 otherwise.

Returns:
the number of edges added.

Parameters:

reduce

public static BasicDigraph reduce(Digraph g,
                                  NodeMap<Node> nMap)
Compute a transitive reduction of a given digraph.

A digraph is computed which is a smallest graph whose transitive closure includes g.

Parameters:
g - the digraph for computing the reduction
nMap - an attribute map which will contain a mapping from nodes in g to nodes in the result.
Returns:
a digraph representing the transitive reduction of g.

m/u

reaches

protected boolean reaches(Node s,
                          Node t)
Return true if s reaches t in the original graph. This query takes log(n) time where n is the total number of distinct intervals used to describe the reachable set of nodes in the quotient graph from the quotient of s.

quotientNodeSize

int quotientNodeSize()
Returns the total number of nodes in the quotient graph.
